text:
Hey Muqarrab! So nice to meet you & I'm really excited to be your E-Mentor :smiley:

A little bit about me: I'm Samantha and I work at the NHS as part of the Royal Free NHS Hospital Trust (a group of 3 hospitals in London). The guys at Prospela sent me your profile which says you're passionate about being involved in your local community and want to get into a top UK Medical university and I can certainly give you some guidance on that and insight to work life in the industry.

Great to hear that you want to become a doctor! A GP or specific area of expertise? To what extent have you considered other roles in the healthcare industry? Would be great to know so I know what to cover during our chats :wink:
Also anytime you want to send a message go ahead! I can't always reply straight away whilst at work but I will get back to you as soon as I can!

Note: I am not a trained Doctor, but I work very closely with them on a regular basis. I ultimately make decisions for our group of hospitals that influence their work so it's crucial that I understand the work they do on an operational level.
Looking forward to hearing from you Muqarrab :blush:
Also - are you Year 12 or 13? And have you started any university applications etc? More than happy to advise and help you
Hi Samantha
Thank you for getting back in touch with me during these hectic times. I hope that you are healthy and well.
I am currently a Year 12 student, which means that I hope to start my university applications soon, perhaps starting my personal statement in the coming few weeks/months.
As far as it comes to area of expertise, I hope to specialise down the line, somewhere within the field of a consultant or surgery - which one I do not know yet!
After one week work experience at Harefield Hospital under the respiratory medicine department, I feel swayed towards the more specific roles in medicine.
I look forward to speaking to you and gaining some great advice :smiley:

That's great. I can definitely help you with your personal statement. Right now, the best use of your time to improve your chances is finding work experience / volunteering opportunities & maybe even finding little conferences (perhaps online given the current environment) that are related to Medicine and a variety of topics, so that by the time it comes to writing your personal statement you have lots of ways to demonstrate your interest.
So far, I have:
One week work experience in Harefield Hospital

I can see you already did some volunteering at a local care home, which is brilliant. Would love to hear more about your experience there! What were some of the key things you learned from that? Was there anything you found stressful/unenjoyable? Often to decide where you want to go in your career, it's jsut as helpful understanding what you don't enjoy!
4 month work experiece at local care home
Both are excellent for your CV. Well done on landing those!
And I will soon be getting one week experience at a local pharmacy
oh wow - that's a good range
What was your role in the Respiratory Medicine Dept? Of course you were only there for 1 week, but would be great to understand a bit more about what activities they had you doing
Even if it was just filing and making the tea (As I did in my first job! :sweat_smile:)  we can put a nice spin on it to make your CV look amazing
How did you find those 3 opportunities (the hospital, care home & pharmacy)?

In regards to the care home, I would visit for 2 hours on a weekly basis. Living with my 86 year old grandfather, I was quite comfortable with the elder;ey residents. My main job would be to take them to their afternoon activity, which could be cooking, cutting etc, but also helping make tea, chatting with them on a personal level and also helping out in jobs around the care home such as filing things sometimes.
For the Hopsital, my father suffers from sleep apnoea so was under f
Dr William Man's clinic, and so I was able to gain work experience through that connection
I volunteered at the care home by walking in there one day and chatting to the activities co-ordinator.
And some of my friends also gained work experience in pharmacies so I was able to get introduced through them and they were more than happy to take me on.
